As a Singaporean, majority of young adults here are well-aware of how authoritarian Singapore is. We openly call PAP a dictatorship or openly-corrupt. Ministers gets payed millions, laws are solely made by one party, and anything we disagree with will still be implemented. 

But the trade-off? High pay, amazing healthcare, world class public transportation, amazing amenities. Personally, I did average in school yet I have no worries for the future living in Sg even more so for those with higher education. Its practically a utopia for middle class families and heaven for the rich. It still has lower income families of course, but they are heavily supported to have the bare minimum which is housing. I love and hate PAP, but I can’t deny the convenience of living here. All that’s said, I will most likely NOT retire here, but I am sure to be able to move to any country with my decent education from this country and powerful passport at the end of the day.

What I think is important is really accountability, I don’t care if PAP ran the government but I want an opposition capable of at least keeping them in check and the public aware. Which has sadly yet to happen.

It's interesting how many people are experts on democracy when there are exactly two countries in the world with true (=direct) democracies: Switzerland and Liechtenstein (although in Liechtenstein, a ruler is also involved).

I am Swiss and live in Switzerland.

The direct democracy ensures that the tax burden never gets too high and that important issues can be voted upon by the parliament or even initiated by ordinary people to be voted on by the entire country.
It also ensures that important issues are not resolved fairly since a majority is interested in keeping it the way it is and incentivized to prioritize their needs above other peoples or future generations. This can be seen in our retirement system which no politican has the balls to tackle since they know that mostly old people vote and mostly old people benefit from the artificially high rents (which are paid for by younger people).

Also, as a friend used to say: The average person is quite dumb and 50% are even dumber. Not politically correct but true.
A uninformed persons vote for any topic you can vote on (not just electing politicians) carries the same weight as an informed persons vote. Or even the same weight as the vote of a person who is a globally renowned expert on said topic/issue. So a party/politician who knows how to persuade the masses - with or without merit to their position - can garner a low of votes. This can be very dangerous.

I visited Singapore as an American and became enamored by its prosperity, efficiency, cleanliness, safety, lack of drugs, public respect, diversity, etc. I actually love the chewing gum ban and heavy fines for littering or amoking in public areas cause even the poorest locations are fairly clean in comparison to US cities. There are signs and cameras everywhere warning and discouraging from stealing or even just to show you the signs of stroke or child neglect with an injunction to call the police. I even saw a sign that said it was illegal to stare at people's bodies at the beach. Probably the worst thing I learned was that the government has a large amount of control over how you receive your retirement money. 

That being said, as an American I am always cautious of possible power abuse, not just it's manifestation. I kind of just see Singapore as lucky. I do think Singapore can maintain itself and become more democratic at the same time, it just requires something that the US lacks as well, and that is education and inculcation to vote as a politically educated and humble individual who is willing to make sacrifices. What I mean is that yes, we ought to teach our populace about economics, psychology, philosophy, etc. but we also need to somehow teach epistemic humility. Just because you took some economics courses it  does NOT mean you are an expert. We need to vote by track record, skill set, and trustworthiness NOT by what our inferior opinion on tax policy, interest rates, public spending, or healthcare are. You don't know better than an expert and that arrogance of thinking you do is what lands the US in conflicting non progress that drags on for decades

The reason Singapore works:

1. There are no entrenched interest groups - its just a country of job holders and corporations.

2. Politicians are not corrupt - Singapore has some of the lowest corruption rates in the world as its poliicians are paid some of the highest salaries. A corrupt government where politicians can steal with impunity is a seed for public discontent. Singapore does not have that.

3. The government delivers - its service to the public is some of the best in the world. Very few Western European or North American countries can match its efficiency. Again, there is no preferential treatment. Being rich or famous will not help you cut lines.

4. No unions, but extremely strong social security, so, if terminated, you will get unemployment benefits to go by. Obviously, the government will breath down your neck and force you to accept a lower paying less relevant job to get you out of dole. However, if you are sick, social security kicks in and pays for your periods of illness.

5. No collective burgain, but competitive wages because the whole society is geared towards meritocracy. That also causes hidden pockets of poverty among low-skilled immigrant workers that Singapore successfully hides.

6. Very strong rule of law - corollary to no. 2. A politician cannot take advantage of the people with impunity. No Uday Saddam picking up women that he fancied from universities and then unceremoniously dumped at her family's door step.

7. One of the greatest public transport system in the world and is geared in such a way that even senior corporate leaders take public transport.

These cause people or sheeple to live a content life. In any democracy, it is usually a very small minority that questions the status quo and drives changes. Democracies tolerate them because they work as a safety valve and also sometimes come up with brilliant ideas that governments can implement and take the wind out of these radical movements. Think of the social security and universal healthcare introduced all over the Europe to defend social democracy against communism. 

In Singapore, that minority is not tolerated. The rest 98% simply do not care and are happy to live better than first world life style with decent pay packages.

Thing is, if people under a dictatorship truly and honestly have nothing to complain, then it's a successful dictatorship. Otherwise, it's a failure. And in reality, you'll never find one successful dictatorship.

As a Singaporean, this video is only partially true with regards to the criticisms. Much of the examples quoted were exaggerated and not given the correct context. Being one of the most highly educated country population in the world, majority of us are keenly aware of what works for our country, why they work and which proposed policies actually are likely to work. The proof of the pudding is in the tasting. Why was there such huge success within one generation? Because we tend to choose intelligent leaders who have enough experience to possess foresight and let them can get the job done unhindered. This is preferred to having democracies that implode because voters may not be educated enough to make good choices and are instead driven by emotions from 'airware' campaigns. Just because the more capable leaders were already captured by the PAP doesn't mean we try to spite them and sabotage ourselves by voting for less capable people elsewhere. The cause and effect is wrong in the video and neither understands the true situation on the ground nor reflect the views of the majority of Singaporeans. Personally, I'll choose effective government over one mired in time wasting debates in parliament and achieving no real outcomes. Just need to take a good look at the USA to contrast. A large proportion of voters that can be easily manipulated by disinformation campaigns in the name of freedom of speech, leading to a good chance of them democratically electing incapable/weak leaders. Absolutely inefficient, no wonder domestically things are still so backward. Absolutely not looking forward to 2024 where Donald Trump gets reelected by the majority again. Freedom of speech lovers will have 4 more years to regret their blend of democratic elections and wonder why the 'perfect' system so often lead to undesired outcomes. Gonna be swarmed by 'freedom fighters' comments soon I would think.

Interesting discussion, very much an example of what I've always said: the advantage of dictatorship is the fact that it can get shit *done.*  The disadvantage of dictatorship is that it can get *shitty things* done.  

The choice hinges entirely on the choices of one ruler and the favour of a small handful of power brokers who help maintain that rule.  (In typical dictatorships, these are groups like the military leadership because the maintenance of power is done through violent suppression of the public or threats of same; in old medieval European kingdoms, these would be the king's direct vassals and the Catholic Church; in Singapore, I don't know who these people would be, but I'm sure the Prime Minister knows exactly who they are.)  

Generally, the biggest problem with dictatorships where the leader's choices are good for their country at large is succession: It's very common for dictatorship to be inherited, passed down from father to son.  This works fine when the son is raised to have a solid understanding of their role and generally wants to be a responsible leader, but wait long enough and you inevitably have a son who'd rather just enjoy the luxury of ultimate power or you lose a dictator early before their successor can be properly trained, and they make terrible mistakes that disrupt the very fine balance of a prosperous dictatorship and in their attempts to stabilize things, almost always manage to destroy everything that made their realm special.  Or you just have some jackass who wants personal power assassinate the dictator and his family and declare himself ruler, which kicks off a civil war that runs the country into the ground (see the Roman Empire, repeatedly).  

Singapore's veneer of democracy might actually serve another purpose: distributing power just enough that leaders can be cultivated and selected based on their ability to meet the standards of the party as a whole.  If you're selecting leaders based on how well they fill the shoes of the previous leader, rather than through arbitrary means like primogeniture, the odds of winding up with a leader who isn't suited to the task are greatly reduced.  Or it might be just as unstable as every other dictatorship, just waiting for the right (wrong) leader to bring it all crashing down.

This is a country who obviously is trying to overcome one of the glaring and destructive flaws in democracies. The only way that a truly democratic structure could be the best for providing a good government (and leaders) is if the candidates were all highly educated, intelligent, well informed, of good character, and honest. There is simply no way the average voter can be a judge of every candidate. And, in many cases, the results of the primaries to pick the party candidates is more of a popularity contest, or the ad agencies clever work to convince the gullible public (as in America). The truth is that most of the voters in a democracy are not able to even begin to understand if a candidate is qualified or capable to assume the position of president and successfully lead the nation.
If a country has an uneducated and/or a misinformed populace, the results of an honest election can be disastrous. Since no one has come up with a way to screen the eligibility of their citizens to vote based on their capability, democratic elections are a true crap shoot. 😏

Okay so I'm a Singaporean and in general though many of the new generation considers the government as a dictatorship/mornachy, it really isn't. It is very much a democracy where the ruling party gains near absolute power for a term. 
Here's some of the problems with that though, people are less seen as people and part of a machine, there is a constant rat race in singapore that's indoctrinated into you from childhood to adulthood, better grades, better scores means you're a better person. 
The way the government is structured isn't bad per say but it makes it very very hard for change to occur. 
Singapore is probably one of the safest places in the world where free press and classrooms might be actively controlled by the government but you are given the free choice to seek out different forms of media and idealogies. 
Here's the thing though, if you are given 2 pizzas everyday, one made of low quality cheese but is free and the other which a better quality but cost dollar, eventually, you will choose the low quality at least once every other day then if you're given this choice everyday and told by the books you learn from about how great the free pizza is, this would increase your chances of choosing it. This is how the government here gives you the choice. Heck sometimes you don't even know the choice for paid pizza is even a choice, this is how the government here trains kids to support them.
A majority of the younger generation are trying to move away from this idea of the rat race or are trying to help change the old laws of Singapore especially regarding LGBTQIA+ but against a system that can change but is prone not though it is difficult, Singapore is far from a dictatorship, it is very much a democracy.

Saying "the inly thing getting in the..." is a far fetched and arguably inappropriate reduction of national politics/economics. Singapore allowed itself to be a work center for the West and excluded the rest of Malaysia in doing so. There are plenty of international coties around the world that have had similar positions. Shanghai, Lagos, etc... Singapore is located in the center of the global export hub that is East Asia and thus is a prime location for businesses to set up headquarters/outposts. Singapore has benefitted from relative regional stability. It is small and thus has a lower GDP/cap:HDI ratio than most nations (it's far cheaper/more profitable to build public transit in a city-state than to do so through a rural country). Asian nations (the confucian point) are far less revolutionary in character than Western or African nations, with respect for authority deeply ingrained in their cultures, meaning a dictatorship doesn't have to spend as many resources oppressing their populace and putting down rebellions as they would have to in another country. Singapore was lucky that it's dictators wanted to build a powerful nation instead of being like Sri Lanka and intentionally destroying their country. 

Politics isn't an obstacle to progress. It's a method of doing things, progressive and counter-productibe things. It certainly slows everything down if consensus isn't reached, but there are ways around this/ways of running a country so that people don't want to throw out the government everytime there's an issue. Some of those things are vaguely fascistic - silencing the media, charging those who levy false allegations or incendniary accusations against the regime, purging corrupt officials, but fundamentally, it involves three things. 
1). As you mentioned, is ensuring that you deliver for the population. 
2). Is preventing malignant forces from gaining a foothold in your country to begin with. (Mafias, disloyal businesses, etc...)
3). Is helping your populace to understand the government's role in crises resolutions before they happen. "Yes, there is a bad drought and food prices have increased. We are working on reallocating funds from research into etc... to help pay for hunger relief programs. We expect to lower food prices at the point of purchase by 7% by this November. We are in this together." 
And you force any station that calls themselves news to air that statement whenever they address the issue of inflation in food prices. If a channel does not, or they make incendiary comments claiming that the government is ignoring the food crisis and not doing enough to relieve inflation but they do not back this up with hard evidence that there are solutions that government officials are choosing not to pursue, you fine them, you refuse them interviews, you force them to remove "News," from their name, because they are exploiting a crisis for personal gain. That's not politics. That's business.

For everyone saying that Singapore has no resources: Singapore's "resource" is being in such a strategic point for world trade. It's easier for countries to trade with each other there, instead of sailing all the way from China to Europe or vice versa. Before Singapore, there was another rich trading city in the straits called Melaka.


But Trade is a different "resource" to oil or minerals  - in the latter, your country only needs unskilled, poor citizens to work the mines. For Trade, you need a stable business environment and educated workers at any cost. That's why Singapore keeps its population rich enough to not disturb the business.

It's still a great place to live, but it's not like every country can get this wealthy with the same policies, Rwanda already tried that.

Singapore is not the world's ONLY successful dictatorship, though it is one of the few, and arguably the best and possibly the only example of a successful CAPITALIST dictatorship.
I'd argue that the People's Republic of China is probably the greatest example of a modern-day successful dictatorship. China went from an extremely poor, agrarian state before the communists won the civil war, then a slow but steady rise at the beginning of Mao's reign, followed by the catastrophic failure to modernise the country coinciding with one of the worst famines in modern history that comprised the Great Leap Forward, before the Chairman's initial deposal, and another slow but steady rise, intersected by the Cultural Revolution and the replacement the previous leader with Chairman Mao once more, marked by the destruction of historical texts, this time damaging the rich cultural background of China, while the economy stagnated, before Mao's death and replacement preceded exponential growth, along with the one-child policy, which decreased the ridiculous strain on the country caused by the massive and rapidly growing population of China, and finally, president Xi Jinping was put into power, accelerating China's growth into its position today of the secondary world superpower.
Singapore is more of an authoritarian technocracy, and not a banana republic type dictatorship plagued by the resource curse.

As an American, I’ll just say that the whole point of multiple parties is to create accountability. As such, a one-party state would be fine as long as there is sufficient accountability *within* the party; that is, accountability for how candidates are chosen in the first place.

The World’s Moral And Practical Obligation To Ukraine

In Ukraine, there is both a moral and practical obligation, which transcends the fact of there being no formal obligation from NATO or the EU.
As we know from history, formal obligations crumble in the face of reality when dealing with someone like Putin. I am not complaining so much as I am cautioning the entire world that if it is not willing to nip in the bud the actions of Putin now, we will most certainly be compelled to confront him later. And the effects of that will probably be much worse than the risk of starting a third world war now.
A world that bows to the will of a bully and dictator today, will either become a virtual pawn of that bully and dictator or be forced to fight him later. As we saw with Hitler, because the world was not willing to confront him early on, the ultimate conflagration that resulted was much worse than it might otherwise have been.
Just as a free individual cannot long endure the abuse and domination of a bullying neighbor, so too, the free nations of the world cannot long endure the abuse and dominance of a bully and dictator among them.
Of course, the possibility of nuclear war is paralyzing, and the present fear of that happening is what gives Putin his ultimate edge. He knows this and wants the world to think he might be crazy enough to use nuclear weapons. We need to call his bluff by letting him know that we will even risk nuclear war to save freedom and democracy in the world.
The world not only allowed Putin to exist but did business with him. Now humanity must pay the karmic price for its complicity. And that price may be a third world war, which might even mean nuclear war.
This is a horrifying thought, but reality does not care what is horrifying to humanity. The world we create and the results of that creation are as they are. If we cater to autocrats, we will have to live with autocracy as the way of the world - or we can stop allowing autocrats to evolve and exist in the world.
At the moment, Ukraine is the center of our universe. It is the focal point and pivot point for our future. What we decide to do there will determine the direction we will take to that future and what that future will be. Will it be a world where freedom and democracy become the way of the world for all humankind, or will it be a world where the dream of freedom and democracy is dead, and slavery and autocracy rule?

This reminds me of my country's recent history (Barbados), though it is a slightly different case. In both of the last two elections, the last being just last month, the current ruling party (BLP) won all the seats, that being twice in a row. It should also be noted that the last election was announced like 2 weeks notice as well, similar to what was mentioned in the video, so there was a good bit of contention there. Nevertheless, as it stands, there's really no political opposition to the BLP, something that has ruffled a good few feathers here and abroad in terms of concerns for democracy, and it really has me thinking long and hard about the whole thing in general. 

The historical competitor to the BLP (DLP) is pretty much all but finished at this point after their two term run that ended in 2018, complete with sewage-filled streets and beaches (actual literal sewage, it made international news), corruption scandals and a most obvious attempt at scorched-earth tactics once they figured the boat was sinking. On the other hand, Barbados has seen serious economic and infrastructural growth under the BLP and has become a notable player on the international stage. There _were_ a number of new parties popped up back then, which at the time seemed to show some promise, but they all really lacked a lot needed to fill the DLPs shoes and go up against the BLP. In some ways, Barbados has become a bit of a one-party state, but Barbadians gladly choose BLP because we know that things will get done, and in a weird way it's democracy, like this is how democracy _should_ work, but also, it's not?.. It's quite the dilemma tbh.

Bringing down a rotten leader is the highest civic act I can think of, epitomized by St. George killing the Dragon. What if the Dragon is good--a possibility that the Chinese mind favours, b.t.w.? I see this as the wrong question, to be reworded as, "Has enough been done to expose its misdeeds?" The fundamental principle that power corrupts is so deeply engrained in my western political sensibility that the handful of notable exceptions merely reinforce it (through their very scarcity). It all boils down to trust, I guess, and the fact that Singapore is a very young state plays in its favour: sixty years is, for a political entity, little more than a honeymoon between ruler and ruled. This is an interesting analysis but as a Singaporean, I have to say that there is quite a lot of Singapore's history that was not properly analyzed especially when there was a lot of focus on the PAP remaining in power. The choice to take this "authoritarian shortcut" was something borne out of necessity and not just a high risk high reward decision. During the period of decolonization, Singapore as an independent state was at its weakest and most vulnerable. My parents tell me of stories when gangs roamed the streets, how there were always fights breaking out that our "ang chia" (anti-riot vehicles) had to come and stop, how several families were crowded under one roof and shared one toilet, and all the stuff that you could never imagine when you look at modern-day Singapore. Authoritarianism is a system with its flaws, but in a time of civil unrest with a divided population, ruling with an iron fist and setting the country onto one specific path was the most socio-politically viable way for Singapore to survive and move forward in a short period of time. We were just lucky that our ruling party was not so greedy and corrupt to begin with, so under their leadership, Singapore went from third to first world in a single generation. This is not to say our governance is perfect, in fact, it is far from it. A lot of the early policies heavily affected the people of the previous generations. My grandparents and parents were hit by these rapid changes and struggled to adapt. But the choices the government made in those early days were what made Singapore the country it is today. Singapore is certainly not a perfect utopia, there exists no such thing in the world. But as a Singaporean, I personally believe it is as close to a utopia as it gets. I would rather have peace and security over democracy and freedom. If anyone would like to understand more about Singapore's decision and position to rule as a "hybrid democracy", I implore you to watch Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam's speech at the 45th St Gallen Symposium. Democracy isn't the only way to run a country. Every country has their own specific circumstance and their own "best" way to rule.

The biggest compliment to Singapore system was Deng Xiaoping followed Singapore's model to shape modern China. A country with 4000 years of history, willing to learn from what's essentially a city state built by their migrants.  

One of the strange system that I feel iffy about, but seems to be doing well, is the public fund for private gains. This sounds like a nightmare, but their system created incentive for ruling politicians to keep their economy churning. One of the problem with classic dictatorship is corruption. To reduce corruption, they provided incentive by allowing a stake in their sovereign wealth fund, the Temasek Holdings, which is owned by the government of Singapore. Their reward structure incentivise politicians to keep the economy rolling, stability and productivity, which in turn directly enriched them in the long run. This tries to alleviate the familiar scenario of populist ceasing power, hogging all the public wealth to themselves, consolidate power with purges then their descendants escape the country when they fail. We have seen both left and right cessation of power around the world, which established a corrupted government only interested in enriching themselves quick before the consequence arrive. That being said, Singapore is still facing huge wealth inequality, lack of innovation as their most innovative workforce would quickly leave for the U.S. instead and of course, mounting discontent from long rule of a single party. For now, the regime and the country is still stable, but I question if Singapore can take a hit from the next recession that might very well originated from their origin, China. When 2008 hits, Singapore suffered the consequences, but thanks to China's rapid rise, it managed to shift its investment to that area instead. Hoping its South East Asia investments to be less affected by a fallout from any instability from China would be optimistic. Unlike a crisis originates from the U.S., which controls the finance of the world at the time, a crisis in China will severely affect everyone from manufacturing, shipping, consumption, finance to even food shortage and very probable, war over vital resources like rare earth, fossil fuel and water due to China controlling and consuming most natural resources on earth. Singapore now has an interest in keeping the Chinese regime from landing on the ground hard, but what can a small island nation do? They failed to mediate with the Khmer Rouge, East Timor, they can do very little other than finding profits.

A lot of the reason Singapore experienced 'good' authoritarianism comes down to the circumstances of its independence (and luck).

When we were separated from Malaysia in 1965, Lee Kuan Yew cried, he did not jump for joy thinking about the possibilities of his power now as the head of his own small country. He literally weeped for the struggles he foresaw in such a tiny island with no resources and then went into depressed isolation for a month and a half.

So, it was a really strange circumstance, with a strange (that's a compliment), highly intelligent, and non-dictatorship-seeking man, and it produced really strange results.

The fascinating thing about Singapore is that is an "efficient dictatorship" which in itself is a contradictory term since normally authoritarian regimes devolve in a way were the government allows corruption from it's high ranking officials (and army generals) in exchange for their support to the regime. 
It will be really interesting to see what happens the day when the PAP loses the majority of the vote even with this rigged system, something that will happen sooner or later because history in places like Venezuela, Russia or Zimbabwe has shown that "authoritarian competitive" is not a system but a transitional stage before outright dictatorship. 
However, these countries are completely different in their level of development and idiosyncrasies because their system devolved into massive corruption and poorer citizens (read first paragraph) and I suspect Singapore will never be like this. But the way this video explains how now the Singaporean government is giving "priority" to their voters/supporters for housing and other rights over suspected opposition voters sounds like a first step to use the state treasury to favor the PAP voters/supporters and this could mean prioritizing a less productive yet loyal PAP voters over a more productive (tax paying) pro-opposition citizen.
Later on, this might lead to accept more corruption from high ranking officials as long as they keep their support to the regime and this is how dictatorship normally work and why they are by nature inefficient and corrupt.
But, as far as for me now, I don't see the Singaporean system with bad eyes, it's truly fascinating and I'll be keeping an eye on how this political experiment evolves.

It is a thin line. One basic fact is that humans as a group are not rational. As long as the prosperity rises and only a small number of people are harassed by the government, the system is stable. But if government action induces fear in a significant part of the populace, it can snap out of control rather quickly, because the government cannot fight that fear with the tools they are currently using. Same with a decrease in prosperity. As long only a few people feel problems, everything is ok, but fear spreads rather quickly. But that principle is not new. 1789 the French Kingdom collapsed out of financial issues while England had a lot more debts, but the government was also a lot more trusted because it was democratic.

5:55 this is an absolutely ridiculous measure of anything other than how rich corporations are. Ireland is at the top which is laughable given the extremely poor quality of living. I live in Ireland and I'm moving to Spain because the cost of rent has been shooting up for 6 years in a row now with very little change in minimum wage. Couple that with the fact that you stay on minimum wage for much longer here than in other countries, as well as the quality of housing and the price of everything else means that your average person is living in conditions that people in many continental European countries would find disgraceful. I'm paying 650 euro a month to live in a city of only 200k people on 10 euro an hour despite starting work when I was FIFTEEN. I have plenty of experience and yet this keeps happening. In Spain (and many other countries) the wage compared to rent is much better. I stayed there for a few months and couldn't get over how much better the quality of life was even though they (rightfully) complain about the cost of living. In Ireland you will almost always pay half your wages for rent at the very least (and good luck getting regular hours). If you go looking online, a shitty hovel in Cork is about 700 euro now. I moved to Cork 2.5 years ago and it was roughly 550 then. In Dublin you get charged 1200 euro to share a mattress with a stranger. I'm not exaggerating.

I think another reason is just because Singapore doesn't care about their politics as much as what's currently affecting them. There are so many times I hear a thing outside Singapore turn political. Wearing masks, wearing a beige suit, building a useless wall. Singaporeans have this "Fix it myself" attitude. They'll nag and complain, but someone will do something about it instead of waiting for someone to do it for them, like the government.

Like when there was a shortage of masks. While the government tried to ensure there was a mask supply, someone went "Let's just distribute as many as we can to people who fit a certain criteria".

Do note this though: Singapore places live ammunition in the hands of it's tens of thousands of conscripted males. If one day the government goes haywire like Myanmar, it's not that difficult for people to rise up. Singapore does not generally limit travel & many Singaporeans travel, work and study abroad. In a full fledged dictatorship it's highly unlikely you would find citizens so well educated and well travelled. It's probably more aptly described as an authoritarian capitalistic technocracy.

As a Singaporean, I was initially peeved by the video title, saying Singapore is a ‘dictatorship’. Singapore isn’t a dictatorship the same way Belarus or North Korea is. Singapore is more of an authoritarian democracy. We do have a form of democracy that requires ALL adult citizens to vote. You are absolutely right about the use of gerrymandering and crippling and disadvantaging opposition party candidates trying to run for office. Singaporeans can criticise the government (the ruling PAP party) and its policies openly. But it gets risky when criticism is directed at individual politicians. Suing and bankrupting critics, both individuals and organisations, seems to be the go to MO for PAP politicians who feel their reputation has been unfairly mischaracterised. Most Singaporeans like me do want the PAP to continue governing Singapore. We believe they have been doing a good job so far. But we also want more TRANSPARENCY, accountability and  stopping ALL UNFAIR practices that disadvantage the opposition party candidates/ politicians. That includes redrawing of electoral boundary lines. The content of your video is mostly spot on.

Really, the US government isn't all that different. It's just that we've been fooled into thinking the divide in our government is between Democrats and Republicans, when in fact the true divide exists between Establishment and Populist. Our government currently belongs almost entirely to the Establishment, and there's a reason for that. Populists rarely, if ever, stand a chance in elections because Establishment candidates typically receive millions of dollars' worth of campaign contributions from billionaire elites who benefit from Establishment rule, allowing them to all but shut out their Populist opponents who have to rely on traditional donations from their supporters. The only time Democrat vs. Republican ever truly comes into play is when both mainstream candidates in a general election are pro-Establishment; otherwise, it tends to be an absolute bloodbath in the Establishment's favor.

Donald Trump's run for the Oval Office exposed the flaws in this system. He had the devastating one-two punch of already being an established media figurehead, and having access to a massive pool of funds at the start of the race. These two factors allowed him to counteract the billionaire donor deluge for pro-Establishment Clinton in a way that, prior to the 2016 Presidential election, was unheard of. This ability to get his Populist message out unhindered enabled him to gain a massive following whose donations were then able to carry his campaign across the finish line in an almost unprecedented upset.

This is precisely why the 2020 election should terrify each and every one of us. After four years of the Establishment, alongside its billionaire elite cohorts, fighting tooth and nail to have the Populist who wasn't supposed to win removed from office by every possible means and failing at every turn, and with an election looming in which the Establishment's chances of victory were looking slim, the COVID pandemic would end up delivering a game-changing revelation. They found that during a time of crisis, they had the ability to rewrite election laws on a whim, completely bypassing the normal legislative process, as long as they presented said changes as being in the interest of public safety. The plan worked like a charm; the Establishment was able to change the election rules in its favor mere weeks before voting day, and as a result it was able to take back control of the White House in an election that it had a high likelihood of losing otherwise.

Now the Establishment is working tirelessly to have Trump eliminated once and for all, utilizing anything and everything it can legally throw at him, to ensure he doesn't return to oppose it once again in 2024. And what happens if another Populist candidate starts to pose a direct threat to the Establishment's rule? Well, they've learned from 2020 that all they need to do is just artificially engineer another public crisis so they can change the election rules in their favor again. COVID may have been a purely serendipitous circumstance that they were able to capitalize on, but I'll guarantee you that should another crisis emerge during an election year in which the Establishment's authority is being directly challenged, it will be 100% deliberate.

So yeah, as long as you look at the American political divide as being Establishment vs. Populist rather than Democrat vs. Republican, our government really isn't all that different from Singapore's. We just add extra steps to the process to maintain the illusion that Americans still have free choice in their leadership, whereas the PAP has completely dropped the ruse and just openly admits that they'll do whatever it takes to ensure that they're the only party who ever holds any real power.

I think the flaw in this entire argument is that you assume singaporeans to have the same values and priorities as westerners. Although I can't speak for all singaporeans, i can say that most of us put the community above the individual. That's to say we don't prioritise our "civil liberties" like the right to protest, but rather prioritise communal things like healthcare, housing, jobs, economy, etc. I also take a bit of issue with the way you present your arguments. For example when you talked about the protest on the MRT, you made it sound outrageous that someone was charged for vandalism for "only sticking a piece of paper on the train", but to me as a singaporean, that IS vandalism, because the MRT is public property. It might not be a big deal to someone who prioritises the right to protest, but it matters to people like me who prioritise the state of the community. It is this kind of enforcememt that keeps people in check and upholds our standard of living. Even though this protest may have been small, if the government had allowed such behaviour to continue we'd likely be in a situation like america where protests every other day, which in a country as small as singapore would leave no small impact on the rest of the country.

Additionally, on the point that the PAP sabotages opponents and makes laws that favour them, yes the definitely do. And that is a major flaw of our democratic system. However, if you want to make the argument that singapore is a dictatorship compared to other democratic countries then that is not a valid argument, because sabotage and corruption happens everywhere around the world. And while the PAP definitely use underhanded tactics to increase their chances of winning, history has proven that when the people aren't happy with what the PAP is doing, they will vote them out of power. Just last year we had a very close battle between the PAP and the Worker's Party (Singapore's biggest opposition party) and in fact managed to get one of the worker's party candidates a seat in cabinet and the PAP acknowledged the opposition as a legit governmental party, even providing them with funds to run their GRCs. It might sound like a small and insignificant thing, but I think it not only shows progress towards a more even playing field but also shows how singaporean's do not simply allow the PAP to hold power. We let them because they do enough to ensure a good standard of living, and when the don't do that, people will turn against them.

So no, singapore is not a dictatorship. Just because we don't prioritise individual freedom does not mean we are being controlled.

As a Singaporean, I wont really count Singapore as to the extent being run under a "dictatorship", due to the associated connotations. I prefer to see it as the primary reason why the PAP has enjoyed such longstanding power, is due to its ability to eke out very sucessful growth prospects for Singapore, as the ruling government. Political legitimacy is very much dependant on the ability of the incumbent government to do its job, and hence the agreed notion at 16:35. This is even more crucial when considering implementing certain maximum measures which although can in essence assure better stability in many constitutions of the country, are in nature undemocratic and raise the bar higher for the current government to prove its legitimacy.
Thus, SG is imo not really run by a dictatorship, nor is it a quintissential democracy. It is run instead by a key virtue, that of achieving a balance between democratic and maximum areas of governance - to institute a system providing freedom but not too much so as to lose control. Ultimately a country's govt system must be beneficial to the country and its citizens in the long term.

As a Singaporean, I kind of don't care. I'm not interested in politics, I'm forced to pay attention to it sometimes because it is necessary basis to interpreting other ongoing things in the world I have interest in. Most Singaporeans are pragmatic people. We like stability, the ability to deliver actual workable solutions, and the chance to live a honest live with dignity. So far the government has done fine in providing an environment for that. It's safe, comfortable, and often a bubble compared to the rest of the world. To be honest the covid situation is revealing some huge gaps, but overall they're managing it okay. 

Culture matters about the politics. Western cultures emphasizes individualism and hence holds democracy as the single best government method. LKY recognized that in the Asian context (culture and beginning socioeconomic state) we need our own democracy for it to work out well. We wanted growth because we were starving and in bad health. Now that the country is much more developed and very few of the population have concerned about shelter & food, plus the overwhelming influence of Western media & access to international discussion, then there is more driving conversation about the existing system. Younger voters like myself, increasingly, vote for whichever opponent party at election, even though we know it has low chances of turning the table (it did in the Sengkang GRC though haha). I'm not a fan of planning too ahead, but generally curious to see where we'd head towards.

My parents say I should consider moving to China looking at future job prospects, but tbh I prefer to stay in Singapore because at least you don't get blacklisted for bitching about the government (or meme-ing them online) lol. We'll see. No one knows how the future will turn out like.

So, just to add as a Singaporean, the general consensus amongst the older generation here is that the trade off of freedoms for the economic uplift and the quality of life was a worth while trade off as undeniably, the quality of life and wealth for most singaporeans did increase with the policies and initiatives by Lee Kuan Yew.

However, my generation, the younger generation, want more accountability and social change like LGBT rights and etc and are voting for opposition we find credible or that can be moulded to take over the PAP as an alternative if they refuse to adapt.

The 2020 election was a sign of that. 

The shift in votes to the opposition was mostly with the GRCs with younger populations. We do not use the election just as a silent protest, but a platform to vote in and build the check and balance for the PAP to stay on the course for our country’s best interest, or be replaced by the next incoming best choice, which is looking out to be the Worker’s Party.

Because the consensus amongst the people still stands, without the leadership and guidance from LKY, we wouldn’t have succeeded this much as a country and become the envy of South East Asia. 

Case in point, 1 in 10 Singaporeans are Millionaires.

Largely agreeable. Singapore treads a fine line between freedom and authoritarianism, and that turned out to be exceptionally successful. The view that the election polls are a form of 'polite protest' is apt.

The assertion of a 'political dynasty', however, is premature when considering the calibre of the two prime ministers Lee. They and their Cabinet have generally steered Singapore in the path of prosperity. Their abilities have shown that familial ties played little role in allowing them to retain power. It is also noteworthy that for all the power the PAP wields, media outlets do expose mistakes (e.g. the misuse of public money in purchasing excess of fitness trackers).

The reason why the PAP won election landslides following 1963 is because they arrested the leaders of the largest opposition party at the time, Barisan Sosialis, who had opposed merger with Malaysia. But once real political opponents showed up again, the PAP used the law as a weapon to effectively bankrupt political opponents. You need a deposit to run for a parliament seat. Practical authoritarian government and dictatorship are two very different concepts. To conclude that Singapore is a dictatorship is fitting evidence to an already presumed narrative.

PAP IS held accountable for a lot of things. It is a biased imperative to think accountability can only be instituted by a powerful opposition.

Often than not, protesting doesn't solve the problem the protesters want to address, and sometimes the motive to protest is questionable in the first place. There are many ways to reach the government in Singapore, and I have made a few requests. Guess what, my problem is solved without me having to protest on the streets. 

And no thanks, Singapore is democratic by legislation. The history of PAP's continuous reign doesn't change this fact. If PAP messes up, it can very well lose its power; the 2020 election already testified to that. LHL's "strong mandate" might be a bit braggy, but he has a point: PAP IS voted into office, and people vote for PAP because it's generally doing a good job. 

If the only way for you to imagine a democracy is in the like of forms such as Trump-Biden debate, a split 50/50 vote or political drama, then I have to say you have a very narrow, if not imperialist concept of democracy. Judging from the fact that you pronounce PAP as "pipe" instead of P-A-P, I will bet to reckon that you didn't consult any Singaporean before making this video. I mean come on, Singaporeans speak English and are easy to reach on social media. I live in Singapore. Born and bred. Here's the quick TLDR. 

Singapore is a country little bigger then the island of Manhattan. Singapore's living space is akin to Tokyo or Hong Kong. Tight. Singapore's elite class live in landed properties and condominiums, again where land is a high premium, are in walking distance to average people. It is in the best interest of the elite class to bring prosperity to everyone, lest an angry mob literary walk down to where they live. Everyone shares the cake. Funny thing enough, average people just want peace, security, stability and enough money, not all the money, but enough to live by. The takeaway for other countries = A family that lives together, stays together. Have your elites LIVE with and among ordinary average people. Have it such a way that is in the elite class best interest that EVERYONE be prosperous. Cultivate a sense of DUTY for the elite class to help bring prosperity to everyone. That's the key. And before this is dismiss as just a manifestation of the asian collective mindset, you see this sense of moral indebted duty of the elites to their society in the works of Adam Smith or interviews with Henry Ford. The words of Marcus Aurelius or Seneca, the speeches of George Washington. 

It is when the elite class is detach from average everyday people, do not feel kinship to their fellows in society, nor feel any moral obligation for their indebted standing in their society, dismiss the noblesse oblige, forsake the duty to God and Country, and instead seek to oppress and exploit their fellow men, that road to ruin begins. In Orwell's Animal Farm, it is when the intellectually gifted pigs started to live in the manor and not with their fellow animals in the barn, that the dystopia future began.

Quick Recommendation - Have your society's elites physically live with everyone, break bread with everyone, have it in their best interest to help everyone, then you will see positive difference in your society. That is my humble observation.

I see a lot of naiveté in this assessment. The case of Singapore is reminiscent of Mexico in the 20th century, which was likewise technically a democracy but had only seen a single party in power from 1929 to 2000 - the PRI. Like the PAP, the PRI is essentially a technocratic, business-friendly party. Unlike the PAP, however, the PRI got to govern Mexico and draw its members from the Mexican population. It was corrupt, ineffective, and utterly failed to improve the lot of ordinary Mexicans - even despite intense American economic aid in the late Cold War, as the US feared that Cuba would "export" its socialist revolution to Mexico. When they were finally voted out, it was treated as a major milestone for Mexican democracy - indeed, as a confirmation that Mexico *was* actually a democracy, and there *could* be a clean handover. Did the result change anything beyond that, though? Not really. Mexico is still Mexico. It's still corrupt, ineffective, violent. It has been improving economically, but nowhere near the levels of the Singaporean model, nor does anyone imagine it would be capable of such a transformation. Which is to say, Mexicans asserted themselves and did use democracy to remove the PRI from power, but none of that changed the fundamentals of why Mexico is the way it is.

Singapore has an early trajectory that looks much like Mexico's after the Mexican Revolution, except that the PAP got to govern Singapore and draw its members from the Singaporean population. The PAP was clean and effective, and highly successful at improving the lot of ordinary Singaporeans. Generally speaking, when people see their situation improving so dramatically, they are disinclined to rock the boat. That is why the CCP currently runs a popular authoritarian regime. The PRI was voted out in Mexico because Mexico was performing poorly.

I'm sure it is true that people in Singapore treat elections a bit like an opinion poll, but that is not unique to Singapore. It happens in most established democracies and is called the "protest vote." I've done it myself. If you expect an established party to win, but you are not entirely happy with them and want to put pressure on them to move them more in your direction, you may vote for a more extreme party. Even though you are also not entirely supportive of everything the more extreme party advocates either, you don't expect them to actually *win*, so the intention is really to try to force a coalition to get some acceptable middle ground. It also happens that when such protest parties become big enough they often find that they suddenly lose support - when they become a real contender to govern, part of their electorate abandons them and returns to the more moderate party, what in Europe we call the "safe pair of hands", because they never intended for them to actually *govern*, only to condition the style of governance of the established party.

In order for an established party to actually be voted *out*, people's living conditions really just need to deteriorate and the country needs to perform poorly. Singapore, however, is not performing poorly. So it is just not reasonable to expect that people would want to change parties - as you acknowledge. Is authoritarianism really authoritarianism if it enjoys popular support? Is the thing that makes authoritarianism authoritarian really the "what if" question? "What if" things went poorly and they were voted out? Would they go quietly? That was the big question on people's minds in 2000 in the Mexican elections. And they did, more or less, go quietly.

Would the PAP go quietly? Who knows? Would the Democrats and Republicans go quietly in the USA? Who knows? Do they gerrymander their districts? They do. Do they stack the courts? They do.

But a context in which the PAP lost decisively, I'd imagine, would have to be one in which most Singaporeans became intensely dissatisfied. That would be a very different social context, one in which the PAP may very well find themselves asking, "do we *want* to continue governing this mess?" That also frequently happens in democracies. For example, in Spain, at the outset of the Great Recession, the ruling Socialist Party was voted out by people concerned they were spending too much - but they were actually *relieved* to be voted out, because they didn't want to have to be the ones to govern during the recession, and be blamed for the consequences of austerity. They thought it would hurt their brand and their image with their base. Better to let the opposition do it, and come out of hiding when they could offer something more enticing to voters than blood, sweat and tears.

Certainly I would agree that Singapore could do with some liberal social reform. It's unnecessary to arrest a guy for holding a smiley face sign. 3 years in prison is a totally disproportionate penalty for taping a protest sign on the metro car. On the other hand, like most of the world, Singapore has been witness to the implosion of many self-styled Western democracies in the past decade. I can imagine why they would be wary. Singapore does not want to fail, and Western democracies have been failing for a long time now.

Some will liken our country to a gilded cage, a utopia of near perfection shielded from any perils from within and without. You can literally sleep on our streets at 3am at night naked, with no fear of anyone molesting you. (though, someone might film and then call the police on you - our neighbors are no-life busybodies) If you're loaded enough, you would love it here. Just buy a citizenship with some $400k contribution. Free speech? Who needs free speech when there's free Wifi at almost every public facilities, clean water that you can drink right out of the tap, electricity that run 100%, near 90% punctual trains and buses, and free Covid vaccination for every citizen? It's literal heaven here even if you compare it to our neighbors just across the Causeway - and Malaysia is no shanty-town when compared to the rest of Asia, I can tell you. That and with no natural disasters, we're literally living in a man-made materialistic heaven.

Now that we'd got the bragging out of the way, let's discuss the real issue at stake here: What does Democracy even mean. Karl Marx consider it the precursor to Socialism and then Communism (an eerie possibility when you look at the current USA and Western Europe), Benjamin Franklin likened it to two wolves and a lamb voting on what to have for lunch. Mark Twain remarked that if voting mattered, you can bet that 'they' won't let you do it. Stalin said that it's the people who counted the vote that decide everything. The list goes on. I have no wish to debate on what 'democracy' actually means, but the fact that Singapore holds an election where the electorate is given a choice and is under no compulsion (physically or psychologically) to vote for the ruling party qualifies it as a Democracy and not a Dictatorship by my book. Sure, there are a million hurdles for an opposition to qualify and overcome, sure, people cry foul over 1 day changes, but hey, the same winner takes all rule apply to every party. 


As a Singaporean, I have my doubts about the actual pretensions of the ruling party. I can't say that living in a paradise makes for very capable or talented citizens either - as evidenced by the lack of local talents. (But we are rich enough to buy them, just like how we buy our maids and cleaners from our less affluent neighbors, and no, I'm not proud of that fact). But when you travel enough and compare it with the rest of the world, I can't help but be convinced that what the West calls 'democracy' looks scarcely more than a poorly played musical-chair for the power-hungry, the clinically insane and the morally bankrupt. Communism had fallen, but that did not automatically make Democracy the only perfect form of governance that should be enforced everywhere. I personally think that Democracy only works in tiny communities where everyone knows each other by name and are neighbors to their leaders; any population bigger than that, we have no way to make leaders accountable since they can always dodge their responsibilities behind all sorts of fringe groups or mobs.

It’s true that the PAP has managed to hold on to it’s massive majority through some unfair policies, but what this video ignores is that the real reason why the PAP wins so much is because of it’s success rate. The PAP successfully brought Singapore from third to first world, despite being disadvantaged in many ways. It’s unparalleled success, along with the unmatched political skill of Lee Kuan Yew, resulted in most of Singapore having a great deal of faith in the PAP, which is earned. If you see it that way, it becomes clear why the PAP has dominated, and why it’s losing ground now, as younger citizens who didn’t live through the 20th century are less connected to the PAP’s past achievements. The fact that this is consistently happening (the PAP losing ground) despite all those additional advantages the PAP has actually proves the opposite of what this video tries to claim; Singapore is not a one-party state. A truly authoritarian PAP would’ve kept those votes up in the high 70 percents, and could’ve. Instead there have been the usual promises and occasional gerrymandering, but really, that happens everywhere. 

It would be something else if the PAP were incompetent or inefficient and still kept up that winning rate, but they aren’t. They have been effective and clearly what they’ve done has worked. So why change it? If there really was an unpopular leader or decision, there are enough citizens who would be willing to switch their vote to the opposition party. That’s why there really haven’t been any unpopular leaders or decisions. The PAP often takes the safest way through.

Can the system be improved? Yes, most definitely.

Is Singapore *really* an authoritarian country where citizens have no say? Well, that’s not true at all.

You see the same mentality in China and other economically successful authoritarian countries. It's like because shit used to be so bad, they don't give a fuck about freedom as long as that quality of life gets higher and the bank account gets bigger.

Singaporeans are pragmatic. We don't vote based on blind idealism and abstract concepts of "freedom" like how people from western countries do. Instead, we vote based on the tangibles: quality of education, healthcare standards, cost of living, economy etc. We understand the trade-offs, eg. sacrificing some personal freedom (eg. freedom to protest) in exchange for the more tangible benefits like stability.

The video is right about one thing: the relationship between the people and the government is transactional. There is no party loyalty (eg. we don't identify ourselves as democrats/republicans like the US) and the ruling party knows this. Which is why they have been consistently performing up to standard because if they don't and cause the people to suffer a decline in the tangibles mentioned earlier, they can expect a poorer mandate in the next term or worse, be voted out.

Say what you will, but the fact that Singapore is an isolated "City-State" of ~6 million people is a very important consideration. It is a small, highly dense self-governing entity and that has a whole lot of impact on the ability for opposition to make a case and the ease at which one group can keep power. You see it pretty much all over the rest of the world, too - typically large, dense urban centers will have the same political leadership and affiliation for several decades and very rarely have changes.

Despite its diversity, that's a whole lot of people packed into a fairly tight place. I also know that there is a WHOLE lot of propaganda that surrounds that country, and when I was there you could sense a general tension from certain parts of the population - especially if you went to the more ethnic-centric areas like the Indian quarter where people seemed to ignore the "littering" laws (that are terrifying - the laws, not the people). 

Essentially, Singapore is no different from any other major city, except it has no larger government that can supersede it and it incredibly reliant of foreign interest to maintain any level of relevancy - It cannot mount any real defense or offense against any real geopolitical power if they piss them off. The same can be said for the population - if there is any level of stability drop, its going to tumble hard because there is no way for them to deal with problem otherwise.

The insidious thing about the government is that they make us think we're free when we're not. They "allow" us to say what we want online, they "let" us travel where we want, and "give" us good jobs. But that's exactly the problem. All this comes at the cost of our choice. We cannot choose our president, or our government. We cannot have an outspoken civil society and we cannot protest things that we don't like. We are kept in the dark about things like the country's finances and our own CPF (state-sponsored retirement savings). We might be living the good life - certainly better than 99% of the world - but we don't have a choice about it. It makes you wonder, how free are we really?

Democracies have proven, again and again, that voters are not informed, or rational. They tend to fall for fake news, populist promises, vote along very narrow interests, or very short term gain, or against their interests entirely. This leads to parties funneling resources into their supporters and interest groups, rather than into investments the common good. Especially if the benefits from the investments are long term and will be felt by the next administration. Tax cuts and stimulus bring political points now, deficits be damned.
Dictatorships have, on average, fared even worse. With no accountability they are incentivized to pour resources into the security forces that keep them in power, turn to mass surveillance, oppression, torture, and personal enrichment, often leading to lack of long term investments. Even if a leader is competent, and benevolent enough to do the right thing, there is no guarantee the one after that will be as good, and there is no system to remove him in time.
Singapore is about as good as it can get when you fuse the two. On one hand, it is not a dictatorship, it has free elections and accountability, the system is in place to remove the people from power if they mess up royally. Contrast this with China, Vietnam, North Korea - or even the dictatorships of past South Korea and Taiwan - where protests did nothing. On the other hand, Singapore has the practical advantages of dictatorships, with long term planning and stability.
If an opposition party wins elections in Singapore, they will have to govern with zero experience on how to do it. History shows such cases to mess up very bad, with no guarantee the PAP will be able to clean up the mess in their successive mandate.
Of course, the best course depend on one's priorities. The Western ideals of "Give me liberty, or give me death", where poverty while "free" is preferable to a well managed, tightly controlled society, would indicate that Singapore should have regular peaceful transfers of power, even if this leads to a loss of prosperity and stability. Eastern ideals of the interests of the community being greater than the interests of the individuals, would say the quality of life is the proof this system is working as intended. Whether you want to call it Mandate of Heaven, or a Social Contract, but it is nothing new.
I would personally say Singapore should have much greater freedom of speech and right to protest, but apart from that a party that has shown it can govern competently should not be removed from power.

In my humble opinion, Dictatorship itself is not bad as long as the dictator is wise and kind. We still idolize the great kings, such as "King Aurther", "Charlemagne", "King Solomon" etc. (Technically speaking, they were also dictators too.) The problem of Dictatorship is not the problem of holding the power alone. The problem of Dictatorship is how to make sure the one who holds the power is wise and kind. In Plato's "Republic", he strongly emphasized a country can be developed well if and only if the the ruler is capable, wise and kind. That's where Democracy comes in. We simply do not know who is wise and kind, and who is capable enough to rule a country. We simply do not know. Can I rule the country? Can you rule? Or others? So, democracy is simple like: tell us who are interested in ruling the country, and let us determine who is the right one, and if what we selected is not the right one, we will ditch him and reelect another one. But Singapore's System is different in that it is based on Meritocracy: not only in politics but also in everywhere. Because the only resources the Singapore has is Human Resources. It is why it will always make sure the Power will always go to the right one, because they know once the power is in the wrong hand, it will be a disaster. Actually, what people really hate is not Dictatorship; but the Incompetency, Selfishness, Cruelty, which the dictatorship can possibly bring up. So, as long as the dictatorship can guarantee Capability, Wisdom and Kindness, it is not a problem. Look at China and Vietnam. Yes of course, they have to make sure the Power always go into the right hand... If not, then all the best... Democracy, in my humble opinion, is not the will of the people. It is a system to select who is capable, wise and kind enough to rule the country. And again, there is a break-down for the Democracy too. If whoever we select is equally bad, incapable and cruel, then it is the disaster for Democracy as well. For example, Athene, the Greek City, was prospered due to Democracy but it was destroyed due to Democracy as well. That's why Plato wrote the Republic: it is to make sure the rulers are always wise, capable and kind.

4:04 Operation Coldstore — these people were arrested for ‘communist activities’ and ‘spreading communist ideals’. Many of them protested against their arrest, claiming that they truly were not communist and had done nothing related to communism. It’s still possible to find the video recording of Lim Chin Siong saying that with confidence. However, they were detained without trial, with no court to hear their sides. It was claimed that there was evidence found against them; however, these evidence were never revealed or talked about to public. Furthermore, some of them were in PAP originally — Lim Chin Siong and Fong Swee Suan started as student activists from a Chinese Highschool and had a lot of influence over the Chinese population in Singapore at that time, so they played a huge part in getting the Chinese to vote for PAP. Once PAP was voted in, they were arrested and thrown into jail. Operation Coldstore — or at least, brief details of it —  is now taught in Singapore’s secondary school history syllabus.

Depends on how one defines 'accountability'. In Singapore the political system is held accountable to the promises that they make by the outcomes that they deliver, which if successfully done necessarily means that there are effective checks and balances in place including in the form of opposition voices. They are held accountable by a well educated, well informed, sophisticated, cosmopolitan, highly skeptical populace - the population are not mindless, subordinate drones, and their outcomes in social factors like housing, education, healthcare, how safe women feel walking outside at night etc. makes it easy to argue why 61% keep voting the same way.

In contrast, the author of this video defines accountability simply as 'the ability for an opposition view to be heard at the point of campaigning'. Their definition pays no bearing on what outcomes are actually delivered or even whether there is any effective checks and balances in operation. There are many political systems in the world where this is the case, i.e. where many opposing views are shared but they fail to deliver on any promised outcomes - to the author this would still make for a more 'accountable' state than Singapore.

In the Singapore system, they don't make promises that they know they can't keep and they have seldom failed to deliver outcomes on promises that they do make. If they stop doing that then the system would change overnight because, as the video pointed out, the elections are free and the system is non-corrupt.

A “successful dictatorship?” If you’re starting by qualifying that a government is a dictatorship— i.e. that the people themselves are completely marginalized from political power, disenfranchised, & have to live under an autocratic ruler who is not accountable to them & can legally just decide to revoke whatever rights they ostensibly still have, brutalize anyone in the country who they deem an inconvenience, impose any injustice or horror they choose to (which they absolutely 1,000% will do if the people ever start to organize to oppose dictates of the dictatorship’s authority & demand their right to govern themselves democratically, to have a say in the laws & public policies of the country they live in)— then at that point you’re really undermining the significance of the word “success.” It raises serious questions about what even qualifies as “success” for a dictatorship.

Like… To a dictator, success is largely just holding onto power by whatever means necessary, silence your opposition by crushing them into submission, & enjoying the power & wealth your autocratic rule— almost always as a crony of the ultrawealthy who maximizes their profits in return for kickbacks & letting them write/influence the laws & public spending for their own benefit, or in the case of Leninist/ML dictatorships, basically just reproducing the power of the political class (in the form of the Leninist vanguardist Communist Party who runs the dictatorship) & maybe building some social infrastructure to put a floor under the suffering of the masses. Do we mean exclusively economic success? & if so do we just mean they maximize GDP or growth (in which case China & the USSR were by far the most “successful” dictatorships)? Do we mean social indicators like childhood malnutrition, starvation, homelessness, mortality rates, unemployment, lack of extreme wealth inequality, per capita income, poverty, extreme poverty, deprivation of healthcare, education, drug addiction (& whether it gets treated), self-sufficiency, human rights, the condition of social safety nets, wages, the degree of labor organization, the class character of the government… I certainly think these are better metrics than the metrics for how “successful” a state is than the metrics most fetishized by capitalists— GDP, growth (there’s food growth & bad growth), & profit margins, which really are only certain to indicate that the wealthy made a killing, even if that means hundreds of millions of others slaving away for insane hours in workplaces they have no  & living in an unhealthy state of deprivation & desperation until they die early. Certainly some countries may measure well in some of these areas & poorly in others, so it’s hard to draw very strong comparisons, which may be frustrating, but the reality is that the economy & society are extremely complex, multivariate things & we need multiple dimensions to give a meaningful qualitative picture of one, so I think they’re worth looking at. 

It’s also essential that you judge things in their historical context— if a state was governing a poor, broken, undeveloped feudal agricultural economy when it took power, they might be the most successful state of all time, but they aren’t going to have as good static metrics for social indicators at a rich, developed country which was already rich & well-developed when the other country was starting out— success is relative & our judgements have to reflect the historical material context; whatever metric you’re measuring, strong progress in the right direction is success. By those kinds of human well-being oriented social indicators I’d guess that somewhere like Cuba under Fidel Castro & soon after (or some other Latin American left-wing dictatorships) would do quite well, other than negatives on human rights/personal freedoms & democracy, obviously which will obviously be inherently true of any dictatorship. And we could mean any number of other metrics, or if we account for multiple metrics we might weight & prioritize them very differently, or even be inclined to measure them differently, depending both on bias & methodology.

Singapore's leadership is characterized as a benevolent dictatorship like a parental relationship of a morally strict father to it's citizens. No one can deny Singapore's success. The two criticisms on how strict their current standards are and a fear of a future corrupt government misses the point that the current government is simply an extension of the collective strict Asian value family systems in Singapore. Most Singapore families raise their children with a strict no nonsense approach and this broadly appeals to the selection of their elected leaders. This stands true for any society if their overall moral and value system deteriorates so will their elected leaders.

But when its obvious that people live good and wealthy with this government, then why change it? The guys in charge right now really care about the country, are experienced and do their job better than almost all other governments in the world. Any other partly would destroy it all in a single year, because, since they are in power for a short term they will use every opportunity to grab and steal money, meaning, be corrupt.
When a government knows that they have a lot of time ahead, they don't focus on their own profit, but rather on the profit of the country.
Elections force politicians to be corrupt, as they see being in charge for 3-4 years as their rare opportunity to grab on to the country's treasury. They don't care about what will happen to the country after they are gone, the next government is left to deal with it.

I normally enjoy watching PolyMatter videos but this video really annoyed me. Besides some of the factual errors and miscontextualization (e.g. over personality cults, or charges of excessive gerrymendering), off the top of my mind, the issue with this video is that:


1) it presupposes that the only righteous form of a democracy (never mind that Singapore is _actually_ a democracy) is the American model where who is in power must oscillate.. and there must be a strong opposition/checks & balances/clash of ideas

2) it preaches the idea that given that since the singapore democracy is so dominated by a single party and therefore far from the american model, the party in power must do this completely unnatural and unprecedented thing of going out of the way to enable and help the opposition parties.. even though singapore goes WAY further to ensure everyone has a vote (voting is mandatory, voting day is a public holiday, there are tons of voting sites, etc.).. 

3) of course, number 2 conveniently ignores what is happening in the US where one party is openly engaging in even more blatant and open gerrymandering and voter suppression, on the basis that the Republican party will never hold power if elections were truly open/free/fair/democratic 

4) and with #1, it also ignores the recent problems with the American democracy which saw the rise of Trumpism, alternative facts, where actual expertise and competence is demonized, and you can be openly corrupt and exhibit actual authoritarianism tendencies but still get away with it scot-free. In spite of all this problems, @PolyMatter still righteously declares , if the Singapore government were wiser, it would move to be closer to being like the American or British forms of democracy.

Of course, the PAP is far from perfect and far from being above criticism, but this video is in no way that nuanced and instead still exhibits the typical American-style missionary mindset and self-righteousness, in spite of all the teething problems with the health of her own democracy at home.
