Nice presentation, but I think a lot of additional contexts are required. In the case of Singapore, size does matter: (I am very much opposition, labour if possible)
1) The PAP can't do what most dictatorship do. Singapore is a draft country, there's no significant separation between military from civilian that can effectively create a military regime. Most male and some female are once the military, law-enforcement or civil defense. So civic is the only path for them. Undoubtedly they are competent to *a point,* very quick to correct mistake, and that is how they keep power for so long, despite not being particularly popular (for precisely the reason in the clip). They are undemocratic, but they are by and large competent. 

2) Size does particularly matter because it's so small and dense that short of fleeing the country, there is no where to hide shit. It's not like in a large nation where you can have multiple rural vs urban community. Or where the problems of the masses becomes out of sight, out of mind. When something big happens, everyone felt it. Unlike say the US where you can outright have one state denying reality happening in another state. It is a lot easier to get consensus of action for the obvious. Also why the PAP are very quick at correcting mistakes.

3) It is not correct to say they manufacture crisis. Singapore is a tiny island with insufficient resources, geography being everything. Our prosperity is tied to globalism, it is not too much to say being globalist is our nationalism. The survivalist mentality is probably the only thing that everyone agrees about. As much as nations can be friends, there is no one we can depend on. That is actually a mentality you can thank the British for. 

Lee Hsien Long is not his father, but I have more sympathy for him because he is navigating in a time of increasing global instability. The rise of China, Pax Americana waning. The increasingly unstable economic models. etc. etc. Those are not manufactured crisis. Singapore don't have the luxury of serious international mistake.

What's often left out of political discourse in the West is: is democracy really the only and ultimate evolution of governance of our civilization? In the 21st Century previously well-run democracies started struggling due to the rise of populism and anti-intellectualism. It really seems democracies have failed to adapt to the post-truth world fueled by social media. Malicious actors within the state have their voices amplified and there's nothing to effectively stop those harmful disinformation due to the need to be 'democratic'. The western style of democracy currently has no guarantee that it won't elect a radical, fascist leader that will bring ruins to the nation and the world in the very near future. 

The argument against authoritarian form of governance is that there is no guarantee that an enlightened/competent/benevolent ruling class will keep making optimal decisions. Even highly competent rulers eventually make mistakes due to short-sightedness of human beings. But with the rise of artificial intelligence it really seems possible that politics can be optimized and the self-correction mechanism can be done by algorithms instead of political debate. We might in the not so distant future no longer need humans in politics. It will be the ultimate form of enlightened dictatorship.

The Dictator's Handbook has an interesting bit about Singapore. It cites it as the only example of a benevolent dictatorship actually working.

The book frames political decisions as individuals needing to win over keys to power who then must use that power to maintain the support of their keys (typically either the military or key voting blocs).

Under that model, leaders who wish to retain power must spend most of their resources keeping those keys happy and can spend the rest on whatever they want. Typically, that takes the form of corruption/personal enrichment. Singapore is unique because they "waste" money improving the lives of the citizens beyond what is necessary to maintain their grip on power.

Singapore controls and governs how people protest for 1 good reason, to ensure that the protest are peaceful and does not disrupt our economy. Look at the US, with the absolute freedom to protest, they have shut off roads, disrupted big and small businesses with emphasis on small business because big businesses have the capital to at least handle a set amount of losses and most importantly, literally insurrected (While debatable by US Republicans) .
Singapore is a small nation, while blocking off a small road isn't a big issue, it becomes a issue for serious concern if Singapore's expressways or major roads are blocked off as they are literally the lifeline of the country. For example when the MRTs started having breakdowns, Singapore economy suffered. 
In additional, as the saying goes, the mob is as smart as the dumbest person in the mob, protests, as clearly shown in the US, have the tendency to morph into a riot. And riots tend to damage whatever the dumbest people feel like damaging. An individual is smart, but put him/her in a heated situation, especially when they in mob and are supporting a just cause, they will feel like whatever they do is right and its for the cause in the heat of the moment. Even if they were to regret it later, it doesn't justify their actions. 
Basically, protests=>riots=>damage to properties both government and civilian=>results in damage and loss revenue to country's economy=>who suffers most? The citizens.=>Government seen as failure.=>want to limit damage and not be seen as failing its citizens? Limit protest so that it doesn't turn into riots.
Singaporeans have the absolute right to criticize the government, just do it in the right channels and and with responsibility. After all. who wants to listen to a fool who sprouts misinformation and conspiracies with no reliable support to back them up what so ever.  
But then again, all this is just my opinion, let the people judge. Judge others as you would have others judge you.

After World War II, only three economies in the world went from poor to developed: South Korea, Taiwan, and Singapore. By Western standards, they were all dictatorships: Park Chung-hee and Kim Doo-hwan in South Korea, Chiang Ching-kuo in Taiwan, and Lee Kuan Yew in Singapore. 

In the democratic world, there are no examples of poor to developed countries. Only a few countries in Eastern Europe, which had a decent industrial base and were far from poor, barely reached the level of entry-level developed countries after the end of the cold war.  In contrast, you can find a few examples of democracies that have fallen from affluence: Argentina, Chile, Brazil.  To make matters worse, the deterioration in these countries' economic conditions has accelerated rather than stopped.  

For the West, it is better to credit the victory of the cold war to the market economy than to democracy.

13:08 is Seoul

Really informative and quite fair. A few inaccuracies here though.

1. The PAP no longer gives "priority" to those voting for the PAP. Now opposition parties who run their "areas" and "towns" (i.e. the Worker's Party) are fully responsible for the repairs in their areas (i.e. elevators and state of government apartment blocks), which will be quickly dealt with as long as they pick up on requests and write ins. One such case which proved as such was when a local influencer, unhappy that the part in her area did not take good care of the flats etc etc, took documented pictures of each faulty/damaged item in her neighbourhood and within 24 hours, all were fixed, showing that as long as you managed to get your local members of parliaments to notice, it would be fixed ASAP.

2. Singaporeans dont generally vote for the PAP because we "like" or support the party, or believe that the outcome is already guaranteed. Its just that we havent found another party that has been able to make us believe that electing them in would guarantee social and economic prosperity in the future. Every party that challenges PAP tries to "defeat" the PAP does so in the most insignificant method - that being attacking the PAP on one singular policy of theirs, not as a whole, to challenge their ability as the ruling party. Its akin to your colleague telling your boss that you pick your nose in an effort to get your removed from the company.

3. Singapore does not manufacture crises. In fact, everytime there is a crisis (AKA Covid-19) its voting numbers drop like a stone (see 2015 70%, 2020 61.24%), and that the fact that we are a new fragile nation is quite true. The PAP has built a community where expats, multinational corporations can come in a build their businesses here. These MNCs provide jobs, partnerships and diversity to our society and you need to understand some of the opposition parties are completely against this, almost similar to "jobs for singaporeans only". As a port city, we need to maintain friendly relations with other countries all over the world and we as citizens, tend not to lean to that. If anything, we've recognised that to be truly prosperous, we need the rest of the world around us.

4. Lastly, take a look at the opposition parties. Have they come forward and shown us some form of security? Aside from its leading party members, the rest of the opposition party members who step up, do nothing to give us a peace of mind or some form assurance that they would be as strong as the PAP members. How should we, as voters, find it in ourselves to even allow them to into parliament? And to be honest, most people qualified to run for parliament, either don't want to run for parliament or they already support the PAP.

5. In the end, lets be frank. We don't want riots or people storming the parliament houses like in the US. Nor do we want elections where we are coerced by military or police to vote where the government wants. We've found a balance, to give a tried and tested party which grew our GDP and comforts considerably over the years. Yes, our country works because (fill in the blanks), but that hasnt stopped any expat from wanting to remain here beyond his/her term. Why? Because its safe, its clean, its comfortable. We might be different but we work. And lets be fair, US just had the least accountable president of 4 years, pretty sure it didnt make the US more efficient or enviable.

Truth Be Told, Democracies come in various shapes and forms; none of it is exactly the same, and all share one common demominator -Quid pro Quo where politicians campaign on promises they may or may not keep in exchange for the people's votes.  

The substance of Singapore's democractic system is based on a premise that the PAP-led government will be governed by a group of well educated individuals who are honest, competent, people-orientated and dedicated to serve the people. The Oppositions campaign on the premises that they will be an effective 'checks and balance' opposition in parliament in order to keep the ruling party honest and on their toes, by asking uncomfortable public interest questions that PAP MPs are too polite to ask. A WIN-WIN  political scenario for Singaporeans.    

For what's its worth, Singpaore's democracy is essentially a balance between the Rule OF law (for the general populace), and Rule BY law to keep Singapore save from unintended consequences beyond the government's control.  

By and large, the well informed Singapore voters will make a concious calculation that will inevitably put the PAP in government while careful enough to select some quality and sensible oppositions into parliament. The mantra that we deserve the government we have elected comes true to mind.

This video is excellent in explaining Singapore politics

12:00 - the idea is that each constituency is run by the elected MPs, through the Town Councils.
majority of Singaporeans live in public housing that is maintained by TCs, paid regularly by residences through S&CC fees. 

If you vote for an opposition, the leadership of TC changes, including how it's handled, contracts, and support from surrounding constituencies. This means that if you're not PAP, then it's almost ground-up with handling the TC. Aljuned is an interesting one, especially how WP got their audits got raided and charged by PAP.

 Potong Pasir, also, is an interesting one, as they were, up till 2015, run by an opposition. You can tell the start differences between PP and a traditional PAP stronghold - the lack of new house blocks, no hawker centers, only 1 bus svc, no shopping centers (recently there was one new one built after PAP came in, though it's only 1 story), no nursing homes, no polyclinics. AMK, for example, has a new Mall, and adj are 3 old ones that still run, with hawker centers at east, central and west AMK. 

TLDR - they dont outright disallow upgradings and conservancy for non-voters, and dont check each voter's ballots to mark them. Because they can just rely on the fact that a constituency with lesser votes aren't getting 1st priority care, and a constituency with opposition will be automatically handicapped. 

and as far as living in singapore goes, everybody is hard at work or school, and with mental-meltdown-bordering stress, lack of sleep, and fast paced life (literally, we have one of the fastest average walking speeds), we want to make sure that this level of work comes with justified compensation. In a way it does tie in with PAP's vision, since it's hard to go against something that's been doing good, for something that might become unstable and unreliable.

right now opposition serves 3 things for Singaporeans -  replacing the useless MPs of neglected places with a new leader (like Ponggol E); to instill voices in the parliament to keep PAP in check; and to provide a metric of the satisfaction of the population.

I think if you had a closer look, you'd see accountability structures abound in Singapore. They may look different to what you'd see in Western democracies, and there will be different trade-offs that apply to these structures; but that doesn't mean that there isn't accountability.

I have always explained to my friends from abroad, Singapore is a Dictatorship disguised as a Democracy. The people here actually know this but we favour peace rather than "fighting for freedom". The reason why elections are so predictable is because they group opposition supporters with more of their own supporters in the same "GRCs". GRCs are simply put "electoral divisions". The number of constituencies or electoral divisions is not permanently fixed by law, but is declared by the Prime Minister prior to each general election, so it is easy to see how they will always have the upper hand since they will always change it to suit their desired outcome. For example, if area A has more opposition while area B and C has more PAP, they would split area A into half and place one with B and the other in C as GRCs. My GRC always seems to change annually. We aren't blind to this though. We complain, and then do nothing about it because we are used to tricks like these. And don't get me started with our current President election haha. Long story short, they added new rules to encourage racial diversity by explaining that only one race can run + other rules that more or less only made their candidate the only "eligible" one to run. 

The political scene in singapore is really like no other. People working for the opposition and those who voted for them only want representation. It is clear as day that very few of us actually want a change in ruling party. We just feel that the ministers are "too comfortable" in their spots and our needs aren't heard anymore. 

tldr: Our citizens are relatively "bo chap" (ie chill) as long as you don't ruin our country. We are doing well, we are relatively comfortable and so we close one eye when it comes to shady things the Govt does. But if things go out of line, the youths nowadays will make our voices heard. :)

As a Singaporean who voted for an opposition party, I feel that there are more factors to add in this issue: 

1) Since most of our housing is Government controlled and owners are chosen through balloting, many Singaporeans fear that voting against the PAP will somehow affect their priority in obtaining said housing. (This is totally baseless from what I know and confirmed through confirmation bias by opposition voters). So it's basically a unsubstantiated fear of government "sanctions" (for lack of a better word) for individuals vote dare to oppose the incumbent. 

2) Peer pressure: When I told my Grandmother that I voted for the opposition, she reprimanded me and said "the PAP has given you so much how can you vote against them" in Chinese. 

3) The GRC system is flawed imo, even though 60+% of us voted against the ruling party, there are only 10 seats out of a possible 93 allocated to opposition parties. In 2 districts, it was so fucking close down to less that a 5% difference such as West Coast GRC: PAP 51.69% vs PSP 48.31% or East Coast GRC: PAP 53.41% vs WP 46.59%. 10/93 seats is roughly 11% of the total seats, by actual logic, shouldn't there be 40% representation if 40% voted against? This on top of the Gerrymandering by the government almost never gives a fair chance to the opposition. My district changed 3 times over the past 3 elections , first it was Hong Kah, Chua Chu Kang GRC, and now West Coast, and you bet you ass they're gonna redraw the borders again since 48% of us voted against them.  

4) Point 4 is a little of 2 and 3, in some districts, some "new" parties with relatively new players to the political scene are pit against the ruling party (which contested all districts) and in such cases some people just vote for PAP since they don't even know who these new comers are. And I have friends who were like "PAP is gonna win anyway, why not just vote for them". In these districts it's basically a free W for the PAP.

Even with all these said, I don't think the PAP are the devil incarnate, I just want better representation and someone to keep the ruling party in check, because even right now they can do whatever the hell they want.

Democracy isn’t perfect so why adhere to all its conventions? Take a look at the inefficiencies of multiparty bickering and impasses. Who is to say protesting is necessarily a good thing? Take a look at the French or Thai protests disrupting lives for weeks on end.

Who is to say gerrymandering is necessarily a bad thing? If the government is proficient and low in corruption, is stability not better? 

Who is to say a shorter public campaigning period is wrong? If one’s proposals and track record is so great, it’s delivery succinct and digestible, should it not be immediately clear to the populace rather than having the need to explain it over and over again for months on end at great cost and a large diversion of time and manpower that could be better allocated? 

Are low taxes bad if they incentivise startups and employment? Just look at the number of foreign and local companies created in the past 50 years and the local unemployment.

Are meritocratic systems bad simply because they allow those with abilities to succeed more in life? Are there perhaps less skilled Singaporeans left homeless and begging on the streets like those in democratic nations? Who is to say which is more ‘fair’ and ‘equal’? 

Is voting for the opposition as a protest somehow good? Was that not how Trump got so many votes from democrat voters the first time around? 

Is full freedom of the press a good idea if they become opinionated, bigoted or disruptive like Fox? 
(The video also fails to mention which articles have been targeted from news agencies to push this odd narrative that if any news articles are targeted, it must be wrong and it’s media suppression. All humans err, nobody is perfect, so what makes reports unbiased or even factual? Most media tend to cite ‘sources’ which are highly dependent on trust between the source, the reporter and the reader. But who is to say reporters will write with integrity and sources will speak full truths? After all, reporters are free to interpret or worse, edit and omit information that may or may not exist. Without oversight, one could write fables with impunity. When the public reads and trust these reports the impact is then further magnified, so why can’t reporters be held to the same standards as public officials and be judged as such?)

The oddest claim here is zero accountability without context. What does that mean? Local ministers and agencies are still subject to investigations. Government procurements and public works are transparently released online and audited. It’s policies are clear and well stated in the public domain. If anyone in the government commits a crime, they are held responsible and subject to punishments. 

And last but not least, Singapore has existential threats, it is not some fear mongering by the PAP. It is not a naturally rich country, it has no resources, no land, no labour and multiple threats to its existence. In the past, there were racial and religious threats, water threats, food supply threats and many more. Today, it’s economy has already slowed and its productivity stagnating. New trade routes are bypassing the Malacca straits while oil is fading as renewables rise. It’s neighbours will also rise in the near term threatening its prosperity while the volatility of the Sino-Indian tensions will have spillover effects to ASEAN trade and politics. Every part of its economy and stability is neither unique nor outstandingly irreplaceable. Without proper and decisive management, it could just as quickly collapse within the next generation as quickly as it was built by its previous generation.

Actually, in my opinion, it's not that the opposition parties are heavily disadvantaged (although I won't say there are no disadvantages for them), rather they simply don't have any game plan.

Take the 2020 elections for example. During the allotted time for campaigning, when asked on live TV what they would do if they won, they had no idea. They kept repeating ideas and ideals (what they want, or ideas they would like to incorporate), there was nothing concrete like "We will construct a new school for advanced learning in IT due to the rising need for IT specialists, and if we win, it can be done by (insert date here)". That's concrete. None of them had that...and stated as such on live TV.

So on one hand, yeah, PAP has its issues. Anyone here with half a brain can tell you they're not as clean as they appear to be. That said, they're the only one with a game plan.

"But if you don't give the opposition a chance, how will you know they aren't up to the task?"
Well...because they don't have a plan. When they did get a foot in the door, they dropped the ball (but that's another hotly debated topic). And most importantly, we are not willing to sacrifice a couple of years to watch a group struggle to figure out how to operate a country. Certain countries should know very well how quickly a country can change in a few years, after a change in leadership.

Edward de Bono has a whole list of the flaws of democracy. Think Brexit. Was it democratic? Yes. Was it wise? No. In the end, look at the leaders chosen. Do they uphold the right values? Is there proper rule of law in the country? Most of all, is there corruption? Are the needs of the people taken care of?

Please be careful with the type of words you are using, particularly the word "Dictatorship". It is no wonder people are saying fake news are on the rise. Do dictators let the people vote the government every 4 years, follow through the results and not persecute opposition voters? I agree that some minor district victories (1-2%) is via gerrymandering, but in total votes terms, the mandate to govern is justified. Try gerrymandering if the gap is two digit % points? How realistic is that? If there is an overwhelming voice by the people to oppose the government, the voting system would have forced the current government to step away. The beauty of Singapore democratic structure is it gives the voted-in government the certainty and autonomy of governing the country for the full 4 years without being dragged down by lame-ass politicking / bickering from all interest groups over every single incident. It is simply impossible to constantly satisfy everyone. If they fail to do a good job, the people will pull them down in majority at the voting booth at the 4 year mark. Screaming "Dictatorship" because the majority results doesn't suit the minority losers is frankly sore losers, which is why these people will always be losers in life: people who continue to pick on small insignificant technicalities as the basis for their larger failures.

The old generation support the PAP strongly as they more or less saw the improvements to the nation from a small backwaters to a booming regional economic powerhouse. So they harbor the idea that in order for the nation to continue to prosper, the PAP should be allowed to stay in power to continue this trend. The younger generation born after the hard times have no way to contrast what hardships the country had to overcome to get to where it is today and are more prone to challenge the status quo due to better education exposure. In other words they tax better, rather than lower.

Singaporeans are fairly well educated and understand that even though political speech is highly controlled, there is "currently" little to no censorship in terms of our source of information, ideologies and/or thoughts etc despite the propaganda machine that is our local media. 

As long as there are free and "fair" (uncorrupted) elections, Singaporeans would consider Singapore a democracy.

The unfair advantages that the incumbent party (PAP) has, has helped prevent "revolving door politics", the possibility of switching between two parties every election just because of a few policies or policy decisions that didn't quite pan out and/or issues that were mishandled between elections. 

"Revolving door politics" is very detrimental towards continuity and consistent governance. Case in point the United States, which elects between Democrats and Republicans presidents into the White House every 4-8 years and each parties playing partisan politics e.g. voting against good legislature simply because of party affliation and/or idealogy.

Given the unfair advantages the incumbent has over the opposition parties, if they still fail to garner more than 50% of the seats in parliament, it simply means they have failed Singaporeans (and Singapore) in how citizens feel/think Singapore should be governed. In other words, oppositions in Singapore may never "actually" win elections, if they do win, it is because PAP has failed and lost.

As a Singaporean, I would say that not all the arguments put forth are not entirely true but they are not falsehoods either. 

As a small nation that is heavily dependent on its connection with the world, many understand that a change in leadership would definitely upset status quo and therefore create uncertainty and weigh in on economic stability as well. Most citizens thus would most likely vote in favour of the PAP and ensure the longevity of key economic/political/health/financial policies. However, it is important to understand that most Singaporeans do understand our votes and we do see all (or at least, most) of our leaders do try their best to serve the Singapore population and this creates confidence in our political system.  

In the arguments about the disadvantages stated in the video, I would partially disagree with the statements. Many political figures originate from the grass root communities and despite the disadvantages listed, they are not at all disadvantaged from contributing to society and enacting change at a grass root level. Furthermore, the opposition parties are not always represented by ideal leaders and resonate with selected communities in the society. With alternatives not always being the ideal, voting inclinations often shift towards the PAP. 

This does not mean that the opposition creates incompetent leaders nor are they lacking in any way. In our prior election (which I voted for WP, an opposition party), they put up strong cases and pointed out many points of concern in the country. This definitely helped shift some districts in the oppositions' favour but I would definitely hope for the PAP to remain in power, at least till the next election baring in mind that a political change in a country is definitely divisive in nature (see Brexit/American political system). Beyond the stability present in the political status quo, one key subject that is overlooked in this video is that our politicians are actually very accountable and public image is very crucial in the country. 

The political system while rather conservative, has been slowly aligning with social mores and the government do address social concerns when these issues surface. While maintaining this image, this means that the government does its best to please the country by improving standards of living while avoiding topics that could potentially affect its image until it is deemed necessary to address it. This has definitely helped the PAP maintain power but also leaves many gaps in the social fabric of society. 

This creates the presence of taboo topics that the parliament often avoids or addresses in an indirect manner. These topics are that I have mentioned prior. One such topic is race. As a multiracial society, racism is bound to happen and the government strictly cracking down on such topics is only a bandaid solution and does not addresses the underlying issues. This is after the fact that the government has tried many policies to bring people closer together, yet, we still see occasional headlines of racism and ostracization. This is due to a more passive approach to these issues stemming from a more conservative governing body that we have yet to openly talk about these matters in a mature manner. However, I personally think that albeit this is not ideal, it is acceptable, as the government would address these issues when the societal opinions clearly indicate a need for change and being proactive in these matters while ideal, cannot address these issues accurately. It is like pushing for the acceptance of LGBT communities in the 70s/80s - even if the government does go ahead with it, the society might not approve of it and might create friction in the society. Regardless of which way you think is better (social mores influencing politics or politics influencing social mores), Singapore does a pretty good job at pacing the 2 scenarios and most citizens while sometimes unhappy, will accept the outcomes of these discussions.

All in all, the PAP has done a decent job thus far and I do not consider ourselves a strict democracy. However, most countries are also on a spectrum of democracy and we are comfortable with ours (thus the 82%). I cannot speak for the 18% as I am definitely part of the 61-82% that accept our democratic system but vote against the existing governing party. I would definitely say that our governing party is accountable (to a certain extent) to the public and we will definitely not see a potential authoritarian rule of police/militant abuse (since most of the citizens who go through national service ended up in the military or police department of the duration of our national service). Abiding by the legal rule is our way of keeping things civil and rational. I will not comment on the potential legal loopholes but as a whole, Singapore is definitely a capitalist state as our survival depends on it.

Regarding the debate between autocracies and democracies, I recommend Gordon Tullock's Autocracy.

Essentially, the major problems of an autocracy are: you get a bad person in charge, and the decision maker is only one person who simply might not know the best course of action (or he selects advisers, but those advisers might not be the best quality, for the same reason, and the advisers don't have an incentive to provide the autocrat with bad news). Essentially, there's the incentive problem and the knowledge problem. In a democratic society there's a feedback mechanism that punishes politicians for failing these problems, but less so in an autocracy (revolution and coups are feedback
mechanisms, but they're hardly optimal).

However, because it's such a crapshoot of the quality of the leader, there's the potential that someone gets in power who is of high quality and outperforms a democracy in a similar situation. Tullock argues that the hereditary monarchy mitigates the worst problems of autocracy (i.e., the worst getting on top) by making sure the person who has power gets it if they want it or not. If there is no choice in who gets power, there's also no incentive to invest in the pursuit of power, which frees up resources for other means. There's also fewer resources spent in debate - what the autocrat says, goes. The benefit of democracy is that it encourages debate, so there are fewer egregious errors.

So I would say, ultimately, that autocrats have a small probability of outperforming a similar democracy (or constitutional republic, etc), but a much larger probability of succumbing to either incentive or knowledge problems. If you're a risk-seeking gambler, you might bet on an autocracy, but the average performance for a democracy will (probably) be better and the potential downside much lower.

I think one must not overlook the fact that Western media outlets are all fully accessible in Singapore via the Internet and are widely read. We don't exist in a vacuum and are aware of the anomalies as the West sees in us; I wouldn't be here commenting otherwise. We've read about them time and time again. Heck, I've seen articles even in the Straits Times mention the unlevel playing field the opposition parties have against the PAP. There's also the question of social media; there are a fair number of activist anti-establishment pages with tens of thousands of followers, and they don't seem to be on the verge of vanishing anytime soon.

Most of us Singaporeans just want to live well in a peaceful place, and in this respect the PAP has done extremely well. If one takes a closer look, however, there is a noticeable trend of liberalisation taking hold amongst both the younger generations and the establishment, the former being more vocal and the latter being more consultative. Regardless of what happens though, moving forward, I for myself hope that the country remains peaceful. I am still young, and I want to live out my years here.

Hi there, i currently am living in Singapore. I wouldn't really go so far as to call it a dictatorship but it is successful here.

I'm quite happy to concede that the political playing field in Singapore is far from even, mostly in part due to the measures the PAP has taken - many of which have been covered in this video such as the GRC system and the strict media controls. 

But I do think that the majority of Singaporeans vote for the PAP because they are for the most part, rather competent. Also on that note, I don't see how dominant party democracies are less desirable or legitimate (take the LDP in Japan for example). If a party is doing well, like the PAP, it is entirely rational for voters to want to keep them in power. As Lee Kuan Yew wryly noted, the firsts from Oxbridge can be found in Singapore's government, the 2:1s and 2:2s in the House of Commons.

In any case, I don't think Singapore would ever fall into authoritarianism (no, it's not authoritarian now, more like illberal or paternalistic). What keeps a democracy from becoming authoritarian are its institutions in my opinion. That's the reason why the democratic experiments in Iraq and Libya have failed, and why Afghanistan is the next in line. On the other hand, the institutions in Singapore are sufficiently mature, and in general the country and the PAP are slowly but surely liberalising the system.

For me, it all comes down to a tradeoff between individual justice and collective prosperity.

Will you act humbly and give the people the choice, knowing that they WILL be selfish and fall into prisoner's dilemma, or will you be forceful and not give them the choice, trying to prove the doubters wrong by showing what could be achieved if everyone sacrifices a little?

Ultimately there is no correct answer to this question, and anyone who claims they have one either is ignorant or has an agenda. No matter what your political view is, I think we can agree that the perfect system of governance is yet to be invented.

The video portrays it as if the individual voters get prefrential treatment whereas the truth is that the districts ("GRCs") that vote for PAP get prefrential treatment. Gerrymandering and the GRC system is quite a headache for having a free election, it can and does force areas with high opposition support with areas with high PAP support, which balances out to a slim victory for PAP. This is an example in West Coast GRC, where the PSP party had campaigned hard in that area, however, it still lost to PAP due to a few small pro-PAP areas. Gerrymandering forces some areas to be under the name of a different GRC, even if the namesake of the GRC is far away from the supposed area. This is why the election map can change drastically every year, and causes most to be confused.

The video presents the facts reasonably objectively. But the major failing is that Polymatter did not fully explore the alternatives. By framing the subject as "more democracy" vs "less democracy" it disregards the situation and context of Singapore as a nation. The country did not choose the tyranny of meritocracy and autocracy as simply an efficient means of developing the country.

Singapore is surrounded by Muslim nations. It had to choose and stand by core principles of secularism. The alternative would be ethno-politics (see Malaysia, Indonesia etc) and it could not afford this. Looking at the situation simply by describing the situation today misses the point that the country had (and continues) to navigate a very delicate path.

The people opposed to the fledgling country 55 years ago were not progressive democracy seeking. I am not singing praises to the PAP but any in depth analysis of Singapore must bring into context the countries surrounding it. The racial riots of the 60's and all the way to the late 90's in Indonesia are, unfortunately, the more realistic alternatives to the authoritarian regime in Singapore rather than the rose tinted descriptions of a "more fair" democracy.

As a Singaporean, I appreciate the depth that you've spent into looking at how our 'democracy' (or lack of it) works, especially with how votes are treated more like an opinion poll, rather than a actual choice. Great video!

I think it bears pointing out also that the majority of Singaporeans are fully literate in English, as well as our respective second languages (Mandarin, Malay, Tamil), and well educated (generally). Unlike other major undemocratic countries such as China or Russia, the government by and large also does not block overseas content (except for major porn sites :/). So most Singaporeans do often consume content from western media perspectives (regardless of their political alignment). And just as you have mentioned in your other videos, we are a hub of foreign investment, so we do see a lot of foreigners come and go, along with their world views.

So Singaporeans (in general, especially the younger generation) are well aware of the freedoms we lack compared to western countries, yet we are also aware of the flaws of those systems. Contrary to the opinions that we are brainwashed or too used to authoritarianism and thus resistant to change, most voters place their votes with PAP and the opposition parties with this holistic awareness (at least I hope). 

As you have shared in both this video and previous ones, we are a tiny country with no natural resources whatsoever. While larger countries can afford testing their political systems with minor consequences (relatively), Singapore cannot afford a 'wrong move', we would simply collapse and vanish as a nation. Which is why we are more accepting of the status quo with the PAP compared to rapid democratisation.

My opinion is that most people in East Asia with a strong Confucius influence don't care about democracy. The poll on economic prosperity versus democracy is spot on. What most desire is to have go to a good school, have a stable job and "settle down" maybe with kids maybe without. 

In the west the social contract is that democracy decided the legitimacy of the government, but this doesn't work in the east. In eastern societies, the social contract is about the government being able to provide the necessities for its people, with stability and prosperity. The state is meant to be relied on, to be trusted, not seen as something to be removed from ones life unlike that in the west.

A mistake many people in Western countries make when discussing east Asian countries is viewing them through the lens and value system of Western countries. This will only leave them puzzled as to why, for example, the CCP enjoys so much support in China. The social contract is different, and to many Chinese people, the CCP has fulfilled their view of what a government should be, and therefore enjoy widespread support in China. I'd wager that if China turns democratic(firstly, it won't happen), the CCP will win the election

Singaporean here, three main reasons why I believe the PAP remains in power. 

One, the alternative views are generally not being propagated. More of such views are available because of social media combined with a more educated population that knows where to draw the line (before it becomes defamation). 

Two, most of us are more concerned about economic growth over true democracy. PAP's policies are favourable to the middle class (which most of us are) and it improves our standard of living. We don't want policies to change every election because of power changing hands. 

Three, the opposition do not have enough candidates of good calibre. It is something that has improved in the most recent election but in the past most of them are a big joke. Just go youtube and search "the best moment of Singapore's 2015 General election" and you will find out what I mean

singaporean here and i find this video really accurate and impressive (except for the way you said PAP which many have pointed out :<)

to add on to the video, i think the most impressive thing that the ruling party has done has really been just taking politics out of the equation in our lives. you might hear people occasionally discussing current affairs and what the government has done, people might complain about it, but no one would actually wonder about the policy objectives or why its the case. these discussions are kept hush, within closed doors but there is almost an unspoken agreement not to bring it into public spheres. also, the public never thinks of opposing the government, "the government said so" is always enough of a justification to do something or not do something. 

the ruling party has understood the very nature of singaporeans. we are an immigrant-based society, and almost everyone that immigrated here was destitute and poor in their hometowns coming here to seek a better life. economic conditions precede every other thing in life, and this attitude has been passed down generations. the ruling party has played into this, giving us what many want- public housing, jobs, safety. and it has also played a large role in further shaping attitudes to their advantage, such as implementing the ideology of pragmatic realism and teaching of the great things that our "founding fathers" have done - giving us stability and good economic conditions. thus, PAP has become synonymous with peace and prosperity, which is why their power would likely not wane anytime soon and the people accept the trade-off of lack of political diversity and freedom. whether this trade-off is arbitrarily created by the PAP or reality, until the day the PAP is dethroned and opposition comes into power, we would never know.

for now, i sincerely hope that the PAP can lead us in the right direction. the PAP has planted both trust and doubts about the future of my country, but regardless, who is holding power never matters as much as his heart for the country and what he would do to better our lives. all the best singapore. i love you

Singaporean here. 
I think what you mentioned about the gerrymandering and legal campaign period are spot on. My home is categorised under a GRC that is literally kilometres away from me. The 'getting charged for ridiculous reasons' thing is also quite real, earlier this year there were people arrested for protesting against LGBT discrimination by the education ministry. One thing that smells a bit fishy to me, however, is the 'vote for PAP to receive special benefits' thing you talked about at 12:35. I have never heard of such a thing before, and our votes are supposed to be anonymous. I'd love to see your source on that.

EDIT: I stand corrected. Apparently that was the case in the past. Not sure if it's still the case but it used to be.

I think most of us, especially the older generation, aren't extremely bothered by the lack of opposition in politics because life in Singapore isn't THAT bad, it's actually pretty comfortable. I think most people are just alright with the status quo and fear that change may disrupt it. Personally, I'm not very bothered about politics as long as the government in power gets the job done, which they have been for quite a few decades now.
However, nowadays I think more people are better educated on our political scene and are more cognisant of the issues that have arisen as a result of the essentially one-party rule. That's probably why the PAP is starting to lose some of its voters.

Nevertheless, if it really comes to it, I think Singaporeans would gladly vote for the oppositions if it meant that we'd have a better standard of living. I don't know if I can speak for everyone but to me, as long as Singapore continues to progress, I don't care which party is in power. We still have a long way to go, but either way I'm proud to be Singaporean.

One thing I've always found funny when foreigners discuss Singapore online is that we are commonly downplayed and called names like 'Disneyland with a death penalty' or 'fine city'. I've even seen people on Reddit talk about us Singaporeans like we're some deeply oppressed slaves living in an Orwellian society. Maybe it's just me and my outlook on life but I don't think it's anywhere near as bad as that. Sure, we may have some serious issues regarding mental health and our happiness, or lack thereof it, but in general I think most of our issues stem from the cost of living and the constant rat race here. I really admire you for the amount of research you put into this video though, it's pretty solid. Good job man

New York City did not ban soda. The last two mayors (Bloomberg and De Blasio) strongly supported the *Sugary drinks portion cap rule* , which limited the *size* of Soda drinks sold (prohibiting the sale of anything over 0.47 liters). The regulation was also repealed by the New York Court of Appeals a year later as well. To say that many governments impose limits on the freedom of their people for some sort of benefit is fair, but to ignore Singapore's distinguished position amongst developing countries as *very* willing to control even the finer details of the lives of ordinary citizens by misleadingly comparing the chewing gum ban to the New York Soda Cap is somewhat disingenuous.

Just wanted to point out that you're absolutely correct when you say most voters who vote for the opposition are merely sending a message - as an opposition supporter myself I do still see the merits of the PAP and do not wish for a hasty transition of power when the country is not ready for it. Furthermore, this may just be due to the unfair election process as you mentioned, but the general consensus among the public is that the PAP candidates do tend to be more capable/competent (this is a personal opinion/observation, up for debate)

It's rare for opposition parties to field teams of talented, capable candidates who are capable of beating the PAP in an unfair election, but it has been happening in the past couple of elections, and I'm hoping for more competent candidates to step up for opposition parties, in the hopes of eventually (hopefully) obtaining a 80-20 ratio in parliamentary seats.

Singapore is indeed a great place to live especially if you wish to remain ignorant of the lack of political freedom, but I do believe having a slightly stronger opposition voice would keep the PAP in check and do great things for the country in the long run.
